Wombat, Vombatus ursinus, 1798       

,

 

,

This is the first wombat to arrive in Europe. It was sent to Newcastle by Captain John Hunter, the Governor of New South Wales, in 1798. Wombats were first discovered by non-natives when the crew of the salvage ship Francis visited Australia?s Clarke Island following the wrecking of the ship Sydney Cove in 1797. On their third and final salvage trip the crew collected one specimen of this unusual marsupial.

,

 

,

The late 1700s, when the wombat arrived, heralded an exciting time for the study of natural sciences. Western Europe was a centre of scientific endeavour, promoting global exploration leading to the discovery of new flora and fauna. The arrival of the wombat in Newcastle helped our region to play a pivotal role in these discoveries, fostering and facilitating the study and understanding of novel plant and animal species.

NarNarrative: This Bewick's Swan was discovered at Haydon Bridge, Northumberland, by Richard Wingate of Newcastle upon Tyne. A male normally weighs about 2.5 lbs (just over 1kg), whereas the female normally weighs about 3.5 lbs (about 1.6kg). The birds form a pair bond that lasts until one of the pair dies. The birds become paler in colour further to the north. Birds in Greenland, at the northern limit of the species' range, can be almost pure white in colour, which camouflages them against the snow and ice.

It doesn't make a nest, preferring to use a scrape - a shallow depression perhaps lined with a few twigs. Four eggs are normally laid, and take just over a month to hatch. After hatching the chicks take about seven weeks until they can fly. They remain dependant on their parents for food for several weeks after this.
LocalSum: Greenland

ColPhysicalDescription: Mount of a Gyrfalcon, Greenland Falcon
NarNarrative: Gyrfalcons lay their eggs in spring, as the cold weather is beginning to change. The eggs are incubated for about a month. The chicks are downy and helpless immediately after hatching, but learn to feed themselves within a month. They normally leave the nest within another 20 days. Their parents still bring them food whilst they acquire hunting skills, but they become fully independent within another month. The chicks have to mature quickly, before the cold northern winter takes hold.
LocalSum: Greenland

ColPhysicalDescription: Mount of a Gyrfalcon, Greenland Falcon
NarNarrative: Gyrfalcons live in the arctic and sub-arctic regions of Europe, Asia and America. The most northerly populations migrate south in the autumn as the snowline advances, but are never normally found further south than the northern USA or central Russia. However, single birds are occasionally recorded further south in parts of Europe and Asia. These birds have normally become disoriented whilst on migration. Gyrfalcons are occasionally recorded in the British Isles.
LocalSum: Greenland

Males are larger than females, and the bull seals defend a small territory and mate with all the females within it.
